content:
er 26, 2013
												I am fairly confident that Payday: The Heist is one of the best games I've ever played. At its heart, it's a cops and robbers game that feels a bit like Left 4 Dead, except instead of navigating on a linear path through multiple maps, you take control of and dominate a single map, and you only play as the robbers, not the cops. Featuring a diverse set of maps, a cool leveling system that encourages player experimentation and mobility, and generally just being amazing, Payday: The Heist is the single greatest co-op experience I've ever had. I think it's better than Left 4 Dead, to be quite honest.Would you like to know how many things I would change about the game?Zero things. The answer is Zero things. Because there are Zero things I would change. Actually, come to think of it, I would change one thing: the game's leveling curve is a bit 'off,' and newer players have a harder time enjoying the game until about level twenty or so, but that's a problem easily solved. Oh, don't get me wrong, I'd totally be up for adding new features--maybe better stealth, more customized ammo, more maps with more unique behaviors, and stuff like that--but the fact is, the game is just pretty awesome as it is.You can sprint sideways.You can use fake dummy turrets to keep crowds down while you steal a man's blood in the PC-exclusive Mercy Hospital level.You can sprint backwards.You can spend thirty-three minutes drilling into a secret vault hidden away in the game's first level.You can yell at Alex for being a terrible, terrible crane driver.YOU CAN SPRINT IN ALL DIRECTIONS AND THE BRENNER IS AMAZING AND THE STRYK IS LIKE PEW PEW PEW AND MY LOVE FOR THIS GAME IS SO INTENSE YOU DON'T EVEN...All of the game's features work well together. Only one of the maps--Heat Street--is bad. It's a co-op game. It's not a solo game. You play with other people, and you'll have a blast. I've bought fifteen or twenty copies for friends now.EDIT: Hey, just because I've bought copies for friends doesn't mean I'm going to buy a copy for you. A) I can't afford to do this anymore, and B) if you're a person who friended me at random, why would you expect me to buy you a game?

content:
er 9, 2014
												Oh man, Payday: The Heist... This game carries so many memories for me. I know it's old, and the community isn't really all that active anymore, but this game still kicks ♥♥♥. Now, this isn't PAYDAY 2. You won't spend very much time devising plans or sneaking around (more on that later), but instead, you have a clear objective, and then you let all hell loose with some kickass weapons. So, is this game for you? But isn't PAYDAY 2 so much better? Well, let me break this down.In general, PAYDAY 2 has a more "realistic" feel, with your characters movement and weapons being a little less arcadey, and more down to earth. Payday: The Heist is exactly the opposite, and it's still great. Characters are fast, weapons have dead point accuracy (most of the time, not always) and in general it's trying to make you feel as little vulnerability as possible. And although you could argue about which is better, there's no denying it feels pretty badass.Another key difference is that one of PAYDAY 2's main selling points is that things within the heists switch around, making things more unique. The original lacks this in every single heist but one (which is my favourite, personally) and it does definitely wear on you after a while, however if your anything like me you'll play them again just because it's fun.I'm almost done with comparisons! Another big one is that outside of the beggining of two heists, there's no stealth, only guns blazing. So if your really into stealth, you'll probably prefer PAYDAY 2.And finally, the upgrade system. In PAYDAY 2, upgrading is quite complex. You have skill trees, even skill decks for bonuses, individual weapon upgrades, etc, making a very deep (albeit sometimes confusing) way to make your character powerful. The original streamlines this: All you have to do is pick which tree to advance in, and as you level up you get things from that tree (like weapons, perks, bonuses, etc.), with you being able to switch between trees at any time.So that's it with comparisons. So how's the actualy game itself?It's fast, furious, difficult, and just plain amazing. Assuming you get the Wolfpack DLC (which I highly reccomend) you have 4 skill trees, 9 heists, and all in all a ton of fun. I only have ONE WARNING: DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME ALONE! The AI is so stupid it's embarrasing. You can do it for bragging rights, or for practice, but this game needs to be played with other people, so get a team.Regarding the community, outside of Europe not that many people play it, so I suggest getting a 4-pack and playing it with friends.And that's my review! Hopefully you now understand which PAYDAY game is for you! (I reccomend getting both, if you can)FINAL SUMMARY:This game, and it's sequel, are amazing. Fantastic gameplay, great dev's, and hours upon hours of fun. Just don't do it alone!

number of helpful: 241 of 273 people (88%) found this review helpful14 people found this review funny
content:
er 1, 2015
												Payday: The Heist is a first person shooter game developed by Overkill Software and published by Sony Entertainment. The game was released in October 2011 on PC, after being released on PS3. The game is owned on Steam by over four million players due to its regularity being on sale. The gameplay is based around completing heists with a party of four people including you. This can be done either in a single player environment, or up to 4 player co-op online. The heists can consist of the classic bank jobs, right the way to the complete extreme of extracting blood from a highly classified patient. You play the role of one of the four main characters in the game, Dallas, Chains, Wolf or Hoxton.  Each member of the team can use a variety of different weapons, you are able to select your load out before jumping into a heist, so once you get to know what is needed to be done on each heist, you can select what to use accordingly. Each of the missions starts off in a stealth style mission, where you have to disable security camera, turning off alarm systems etc. Whether you complete these tasks successfully or not without being seen will determine how the rest of the heist will carry out.  These starting missions are done really well, and you will be fully immersed since most of them have you sneaking around a pitch black building trying to out manoeuvre the guards. A lot of the missions also come with the added obstacle of civilians – these are crucial in any of the heists as you can keep them hostage and use them as bargaining trades should one of your other team mates be captured by the police too. Whilst you can spend a good portion of the game in stealth and hopefully not being noticed, a good portion of the game will also be spent with you going all guns blazing as you attempt to fend off an almost endless stream of enemy police and SWAT.  The gunplay in Payday really well done. All of the guns feel as powerful as you would expect, and the choice of weapons is pretty big when compared to other FPS games.  Ammo does become a problem with your primary weapon since you’ll be shooting this off constantly at points, but can be easily countered by the abundance of pickups of ammo off dead enemies. Even though Payday is almost four years old at this point, it is still a really good looking game, especially when you ramp up the resolution to 4k. Originally I thought the game was made using the Source engine due to the familiarities in the graphics with the likes of Half Life 2 and Left 4 Dead, but the game is made using an engine called Diesel (made by GRIN, who are now defunct unfortunately). There are a couple of textures which are very low resolution which is a shame, but I can forgive this a bit given that a lot of the levels are actually fairly big, so this must have been done to reduce the need for loading screens.  The game has a really good ragdoll simulation too, when you are mowing down the enemies, they don’t just die in a normal fall to the floor fashion, each death is individually animated depending on where/how they were shot, which adds to the originality slightly. Payday is fully voice acted and done really well at that; the game is almost narrated by what seems to be someone behind the scenes instructing your team on what to do next on the heist. You’ll get remarks back from the rest of the team in responses to objectives being completed and you’ll also get a lot of radio chatter when you are in firefights with the police too. This is a really hard game. The first couple of heists come with the option to play them on easy mode; these must really be the games tutorial since they can be completed without any real problems; yet once you reach the third or fourth mission, the difficulty takes a big ramp up and you’ll actually find yourself either failing missions from not completing objectives, or because you have died or been taken into custody. I had to replay each of the last few stages of the game multiple times before I was able to successfully complete the heists. Even though the ramp in difficulty felt really harsh at the time; I began to enjoy the game even more because of it; because it’s not just as simple as a “get in and out” job, it forces you to plan your every move, and you will tread with caution around every corner because of the unknown ambush that awaits you. The game also has another two difficulty levels to be played on, Hard and overkill mode – these are modes which should not even be considered when playing on single player because you will not stand a chance. I tried the overkill mode out and it is just absolute carnage. I will definitely be asking friends to join in a game to give this mode a proper try out. Whilst all of the missions have the same key objective, and there is really only one way to complete said objective, it can lead to a little repetitive gameplay. The game does however try to counteract that by adding a little bit of randomness into the stages by shaking things up a bit; such as locations the locations of key civilians that you need to keep hostage, meaning you still have to go searching through the whole building to find them rather than rushing to the one place. Each of the levels has some form of random element to it which is nice to see, since you will be playing the same six or seven heists over and over again.I have put about twenty hours into Payday: The Heist so far and see no end in sight for it at the moment. There is still a really active multiplayer scene if you want to just find pick up groups with randommers, but I would highly recommend playing this with a bunch of friends on Skype to get the full experience out of it. The added levels of difficulty also adds plenty of replay ability too; meaning you will not run out of interesting content for a long while with this title. The game does have one piece of DLC which includes new weapons and two new heists, which is a worthwhile piece of DLC. The game is also extremely technically sound too; I was able to play on 4k resolution with all of the graphic options maxed out and I was still able to hit the heights of 160 FPS, so this is one of the best optimized games out there at the moment.  Keyboard and mouse is recommended to play with, given the FPS nature.Overall, Payday: The Heist is an extremely good game; one that I am surprised it has taken me so long to play, and one that I will certainly be keeping installed on my machine because of the high replay ability factor. The game is also very cheaply priced at £10,99 – but like I said at the start, the game is always going on sale, and most of the time it is for 90% off; at that price, is it an absolute no brainer to pick it up – you may as well pick up the four pack for yourself and friends whilst you are at it.  Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Not Recommended3) Only recommended when on sale4) Recommended5) Highly recommended6) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

er 28, 2013
												When I got PAYDAY 1 on a steam sale, I didn't play it till my friends got it. And now it's one of my favorite games. Even though PAYDAY 2 is out and I find that game really fun, I still come back to this game because the 2 games have 2 different play styles. PAYDAY 2 is more realisic and strategic, while PAYDAY 1 feels like it's more Left 4 Dead or Mass Effect 3 multiplyer. It also feels more fast paced, sending larger waves of enemies in maps that offer poor cover causing the player to use their unlimited sprint, and 0 reduction on your speed due to the armor you must wear to survive, to dodge and return fire on maps that contain both close and long range encounters. Both of the PAYDAY games are on my list of best games I've ever played.I highly recommend these games.

content:
er 23, 2015
												Started to play this game without too much expectations when the game was free for a day, since it has only a limited number of maps. I certainly didn't expect that this game would be fun even after 1k or even 2k hours. Admittedly this game has lots of flaws, but in part that's what makes it such a great game. The random elements in the game, spawns, enemy pathing and to a lesser extend the objectives, make the game unpredictable and failure is always around the corner. Unlike some Co-op PvE games out there, you actually have to play tactical and watch your HP (using "shoot and cover") to complete the heists on the higher difficulties (and for beginners even on the lower ones). Failing to do so will get you punished (although you can get away with it to some extend when playing with a VERY good team) and in all likeliness gets your character killed.Besides the satisfaction of beating the game on the highest difficulties with a good team, you can basically make it as hard on yourself as you want. If the default difficulties aren't enough, install DorHUD and play on an even higher difficulty with even more spawns (and yes, this makes a huge difference). Seeing all those helmets flying is a reason to keep playing the game and there's always room for improvement: more kills per minute, better accuracy, fewer downs, faster completion of the heist or just competing to be the best in the stats at the end of the heist when playing with other players, which can make for incredibly fun games ;).The only downsides of this game is the crappy bots (although this can be seen as a factor that makes the game harder) and the fact that there are quite a few cheaters. As a programmer and creator of (an attempt of) an anticheat module (+more), DorHUD, it's actually part of the challenge to find ways to beat the cheaters or at least expose them.In fact, I didn't only have fun playing the game but also improving it. It's one of those things that are not for one or a small number of "uses" and I can get to enjoy the changes every time I play it. Of course there are also a number of downsides to this, but it feels good to help improve a game that I enjoy playing.Since this is a review, maybe I should mention that it's worth even its full price. On sale it's only €2.48 (€3.47 with the soundtrack DLC that gives you an extra set of masks and some awesome music). It's roughly the price of one glass of beer, but you can play this game for a lot longer than you can enjoy that beer. You can even play this game after having drunk lots of beers (or vodka, if you prefer that).

content:
r 16, 2014
												Imagine Left 4 Dead except you're shooting cops instead of zombies.There's a level progression system in the game just like in the sequel, but you don't have to worry about any of the RPG ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t elements, just level up and spend points. Imagine more like Killing Floor where playing the game gives you progress  on each class. You can grind it out to get there faster, but that'll go against what the game's pushing you towards.People say it's comparable to Payday 2 in that they're the same characters and world, etc. They're wrong. The game is paced completely differently: heists aren't meant to be quick in-and-out situations, they're long, gruelling marathons you have to push through. They also don't function on an "all or nothing" reward system. If you fail right at the end, that's okay, you still get money (experience) for every objective you completed along the way. It's not as rage inducing as ♥♥♥♥ing up a Big Bank stealth right as you're opening the vault, then having to run and get the god damn drill because alarms went off.That's another thing, there's not really stealth save for one or two missions. Don't be a ♥♥♥♥in' ♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥. When you ask yourself "Are we rushin' in, or are we goin in sneakypeaky like?", the answer should always be the former. Stealth in this game is a lot harder, and it's more of a dickwaving contest kind of situation when you can stealth the few maps, rather than being the optimal strategy necessarily.Overall, it's worth picking up even if you have Payday 2. It's not like the Left 4 Dead series in the regards that L4D2 replaces the 1st in every way, they're just completely different games with different mechanics.

content:
4, 2015
												Payday The Heist is an amazing game that you should not buy for full price. It goes on sale for five dollars at least four times a year, and then you'll probably be able to grab the Wolf Pack for 99 cents, which is almost necessary to feel like you got the full game. If you've played Payday 2, I need to warn you that the two games are fundamentally similar, but that's where it stops.  Payday:The Heist does not have as many mechanics as Payday 2; you will always be a speedy, slightly tanky glass cannon who is in danger of running out of ammo and must take cover to survive prolonged assaults. But this gives the game a tension and skill ceiling that really augments the gameplay. Payday:The Heist is much more scripted than Payday 2; in general you are playing the heists the way the developers intended and some may find that repetitive. But the heists are SO MUCH BETTER than in Payday 2! Nothing in Payday 2 comes close to the sheer creativity and versatility of what every heist in Payday:The Heist throws at you. It's very tough to get bored when a single heist involves you visiting a hospital, restraining all the civilians, impersonating doctors, breaking into quarantine, drawing and purifying blood samples, restarting the power to get the elevator working, crashing into the morgue and commandeering an ambulance for the escape. It's really a kickass game and you're missing out if you don't try it.

content:
ber 30, 2014
												Once you start up Payday you can instantly see the resemblance to Heat, a Michael Mann-directed action movie. Every level is about a heist - you go in, you grab the money and you get out. In the meantime, dozens (if not hundreds) of cops are hurled against you. The 4 of you must work together to survive the level.Every level has sections. You always have to do something before you can advance. For instance, you are in a hospital where your job is to steal blood samples. However, in order to proceed to the section of the special patients you need to cut through a door with a saw. These machines usually require activation. Still, you need to remain close by to see if they stop so that you can start them up again.The waves of enemies get more frequent and dangerous. Same goes for the bank mission: you cut through the safe, but oh wait, you need some thermite to be able to enter the vault.Payday is one of those games where if you complete the levels you have pretty much seen everything. BUT! You have new weapons and other equipment to unlock once you level up. This so-called reputation level goes up till 193 and the higher level you are the more money you need to achieve the next level.Essentially, the replayability goes along the road Killing Floor has. Higher levels make you stronger (due to the new equipment) so you are able to pick a higher difficulty and replay the heists once more. Or die trying as this game is VERY difficult. Even on normal difficulty you will sweat to see the end of the road. And then you have at least 200 achievements waiting to be unlocked. :)PAYDAY is a fun game. If you have a lot of time on your hands and you like "farming" this is for you.

												Comparing this game to PAYDAY 2, I generally prefer PAYDAY: The Heist for the following points:1. The "loud" is more fun here than in PD2.2. "Diamond Heist" doesn't have any client lag during stealth.3. The DLC is worth the price compared to many other PD2 DLCs.4. Masks are better and more in focus than in PD2.5. It more likely focuses you to play with other people, than solo.    - The heists are tough on highest difficulty, most of them impossible to be done with 2 standard players, sometimes even 3 standard players.6. Bain interacts more with the crew than he does in PD2.7. 2h Overdrill on Overkill 145+8. The Overkill 145+ difficulty.9. Overkill 145+ in general is more difficult than Death Wish (except you play PD2, PD:TH style)10. Undercover special waves...I prefer playing PD2 for the following reasons:1. Way more heists.2. You can easily solo run most of the heists (due to stealth).3. Stealth may be more interesting if you build the correct "challenges".4. You have more options what you could do in PD2, than in PD:TH.General ups (+) and downs (-) (most of them already mentioned):+ Way more co-op based+ It's harder (on the highest difficulty, default)+ Love those masks...+ Very nice soundtracks+ Focus on co-op- No Mercy has certain stealth issues- There's no focus on stealth in PD:TH, it's in general about "loud"- Singlplayer works on Hard difficulty but is a pain on higher difficulties- Lots of hackers who can ruin your gaming experience.There's probably even many more points, which I probably forgot to mention. :)

content:
er 15, 2016
												Many people compare PDH and PD2 together saying one is better than the other. They're both great games, however, they both exel in their own fields. In this review, I'll cover what PDH does better than PD2.  Firstly, we have the fluidity of the animations. Hot damn, those animations feel good. Just the feeling of reloading an AMCAR so quickly and effectivly gives me a great feeling of satisfaction. When chaining these animations together, it feels fluid, not jerky. On the contrast, the PD2 animations can feel jerky when put together making it not as satisfying to move around, reload, shoot. Secondly, we have the desync. This is a HUGE problem with PD2, however, I have found no instances where it is nearly as bad in PDH. People move where they are, not where they've been. Everything feels like it's not run clietside, but rather on a server where everyone has the same ping and latency. Lastly, we have the difficulty. PDH is MUCH harder than PD2, and it shows. The average success rate for heists is about 25%. Playing on normal doesn't just make the cops mindless drones like in PD2. This may be due in part to the low health and armor of the characters, but it shows. The game is rewarding and punishing. Now, for the downfalls. PDH doesn't have as many hesits as PD2, not as many weapons, not as many gagets. It doesn't even have skills. However, it instead has a RPG like level system which makes you work to level up all your skills. It is rewarding and difficult to get where you want. In the end, PDH is a much better feeling game to play, however, it does not have the new shiny look of PD2 with all its new heists and weapons. This game is for those who want a challenge from the normal rinse repeat of PD2. Not for the faint of heart (you've been warned!).

er 26, 2015
Nominee for the "Test of Time" awardThe best co-op game out there which 4 friends (or 4 total strangers) can have a blast playing the role of a high profile carrier criminal.If you like in-game eye candy over gameplay, play changing builds, crafting masks, modding guns this game isn't for you, check the other game.General Info:♠ Total of 9 heists to attempt, 7 from base game & 2 from Wolfpack DLC. Without the DLC you can still join lobbies running them but not be able to get few achievements tied with the 2 heists.♠ 5 Difficulties, easy(1st 2 heists only), normal, hard, overkill, overkill145+ & new addition of overkill193 (modified overkill145+) from DorHUD*.Pros:1. Very high replay value.2. Large heist areas, which you have ample space to run around.3. Good untiring graphics 4. Nice sounds. 5. Competitive Steam Achievements & challenges to complete.Cons: & some remedies 1. Cheaters -Even though this is not a PvP game there are a lot of pathetic fks who want to ruin your game. There isn't any built-in cheat protection, so it's a good idea to do a quick Shift+Tab -> "View Players" & check the stats of the players in the lobby. Having many abnormal heist finishing times, having masks which shouldn't have (not always a cheater though) are some indicators a cheater in your lobby. You may want to check out DorHUD* which will give you some useful information about players in your lobby & help you ban cheaters permanently.2. Disconnects - If it takes very long time to connect to the lobby there is a good chance you'll disconnect during the play.3. Some rare bugs - like falling out of the map*DorHUD http://steamcommunity.com/groups/dahm4pdGet a 4 pack & gift to 3 good friends or go public find some good friends & have fun!

content:
3, 2016
												I have Payday the Heist and Payday 2 and after 2250+ gameplay hours still loving the simplicity of Payday the Heist. If i have to compare part 2 with part 1 then Payday 2 is more a CARRYBAG SIMULATOR wich is litterly a cashcow with everymonth new DLC. Overkill is so ORIGINAL that they even copied the Wolf Pack DLC from Payday the Heist to Payday 2. What i also dislike from Payday 2 is that you have to choose what armor and what gun you gonna use depending on your playstyle (Loud or Stealth). And giving point to Skilltrees to your character. In Payday the Heist beside a silenced handgun doesn't it matter what armor you take or gun compared to danger meter. There is no Stealth or Loud meter in Payday the Heist. That is the main reason why i like the simplicity from part 1. Not much weapons, but good and challenging enough. I get also a lot Payday 2 players in my Payday the Heist game server and all are complaining that Payday the Heist is pretty HARDCORE / much more difficult compared to Payday 2. What Deathwish or overkill is in Payday 2 is in Payday the heist more hard or normal. Find good players then you start loving the game. Communication and be nice to crewmembers is the key for beating the game. Overkill 145+ or Overkill 193+ with DorHud mod will be much easier if you have the right people in your surrounding.Payday the Heist has also few disadvantages, like no restart functionallity online. You have to die all together or shut server down and hope that the players will come back or you have to reïnvite them. Payday 2 has instantly build in option for restart online game. Payday the Heist has not so much levels. In beginning there where even less levels. Because No Mercy did not excist and later came the DLC Wolfpack. Although the support of Payday the heist is ended, game is pretty old (2011), i have still a wish for new DLC for extra levels. In total there are 9 levelsWith DorHud mod thanks to DorentuZ there is a restart functionallity added. You can also skip game intro's. Best part of the mod is : It detects cheaters!!!! It reports players who have a VAC-ban or do things that normally not can be done. You can kick them permanently if you want that. Trust me Payday the Heist does have a lot cheaters!! DorHud also fix a lot game related bugs that Overkill never before has fixed.More info : http://steamcommunity.com/groups/dahm4pdFrom what other players told me Payday 2 has also problems with cheaters. I stopped playing Payday 2 because i don't like the way how Overkill use Payday 2 as a Cashcow with all the DLC every month. Payday the Heist has sometimes troubles with bugs, but the game is pretty good. Some bugs could be irritating, if some one leave your server in No Mercy while loading level, the bot will stay in elevator and the level cannot be started (for example). In some levels you get shot by Swat or kicked by Cloaker, tazed by a Tazer trough wall or you can do shieldsurfing (Wallhacks).Some glitches are also in your benefit, like standing in Medic or Ammo bag will give you armor. So if you need to reload, hide in a bag. If you are almost dead, stand in a bag. If swat is reloading walk out the bag and shoot him. In Heatstreet if you hide behind a dumpster/container in a corner you can slam swat a lot without getting hit. Handy if you are low on ammo or health and need to bring your teammates back.The game maybe from end 2011, it is still fun to play. You will fall down a lot in the beginning, but keep trying then you gonna love it. I stopped with this game in the beginning because it was to difficult. 1 year later i did gave the game a second chance and i am still loving it. For me this game is worth every penny/dollar/euro.

number of helpful: 28 of 35 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												This game is all about killing 'cops' or 'sprites' depending how you look at things.In fact I actually have met a real live cop that plays this...Dead set! True! The conversation in game went something like this...Kyzka: So what you do for work?Cpt Bob: I'm a cop in real life.Kyzka: What? Seriously?Cpt Bob: Yeah.Kyzka: Isn't that like living a double life or something? A cop playing a video game where you’re a bad guy that kills cops for a living...Cpt Bob: It depends, I view it more as I’m in training learning all the things I should not do.Kyzka: Is that why you’re forever in donut shops?Cpt Bob: Exactly we try our best to arrive several days after the incident that way this sort of killing cop thing never happens...In game Cops pretty much arrive in waves the millisecond you start to look at someone the wrong way. Just like Payday 2 there are special enemies in the way of Tasers, cloakers, shields, bulldozers and snipers that spawn in frequently to stop you from getting your pay dirt. However unlike payday 2 the special enemies often act quite differently. For instance Bull dozers move much more faster than they do in payday 2, though they don't have as much health, still if you get shot twice from them it’s more often than not 'man down'. Tasers will often come in pairs and strike instantly. Cloakers have no warning sound that they are close by and most of the time will pounce on you when you’re trying to interact with something or someone. Shields other than the Gl40, there is no other gun which can penetrate their shield. Forget you’re Gl40 and the only answer left is to quickly try and flank them. Snipers in the droves are undoubtedly the worst. Every time I try the level undercover on 145+ I openly weep when I'm informed I have to go to the roof.The second biggest difference between this and Payday 2 is that ALL the maps are LOUD. None of them are 'True' stealth. Granted 'Diamond Heist' can be done stealthily on the easier levels, but try it on 145+ and it’s all guns blazing again. Sadly the stealth side of things was never properly instituted in this version of payday and so playing as a pacifist would never be a real option most of the time. There are only 9 maps in total with four different difficulty settings with 145+ being the hardest. (This is not including the fact that someone has created a mod which creates a 193+ level for those that love to experience sheer pain).The developers Overkill have finished with the game and have moved all their focus on Payday 2 even recreating the same levels from this one to there. So most people ask the obvious question, 'Why bother to play PAYDAY the Heist?'1) For the experience. Since both the skill tree and the special enemies react differently there is a much more rewarding experience in the level of difficulty fighting in comradery with three other team mates against the relentless sheer hell of countless waves in this one than you might experience in Payday 2. Since all capped 193 players have the same instruments at each other’s disposal it’s all about game play and team work. Have one person acting alone and it’s probably game over for the whole team. This game is so much harder, that I’ve actually seen people who have spent 5,000 hrs plus be taken out within seconds by a cloaker or a taser. Having said that the game also offers fewer enemies for those that try each map solo without bots. This has given rise to the gauntlet of challenges from die-hard fans in the fool hardy attempt of showing off their skills as they venture alone. Here is an example of two professionals who have raised to that challenge...


YouTube™ Video: PayDay: The Heist - First World Bank Overkill 145+ Solo (No Bots) 

			Views: 7,219		

			A super awesome run where I show them who's the boss. Made on 30/06/15.		




YouTube™ Video: [PAYDAY: The Heist] Panic Room, Overkill 145+, Solo (no bots) 

			Views: 10,002		

			I was really surprised even being able to pull this off once. O_o I can say though, RNG matters quite a lot. ^^ However, it's still hard even with good RNG. :P		

2) The history of the Original secret vault and what gamers had to do to get there is also a rich part of gaming history and to attempt it yourself is a 'must do' for any serious gamer out there . Here is a video explaining it all in detail... https://youtu.be/j7nFAURAGEM?list=PLv2Qcu6n6_mI9QeFdDv_xDSe5WL-6PuslSo, basically first you need to do all the heists on 145+ to get the golden mask. Then play the first world bank with three other people each wearing a golden mask standing in your respective positions, next you will have a 2hr constant onslaught of the hardest enemies  while you wait for the drill to get through. Only to be confronted by another room which requires a correct code to be entered into the floor tiles to avoid being gassed to death. Then you will get rewarded with one of the most beautiful vaults you will ever see. Some even claim that sending the video of the above adventure to Overkill will result with you getting a special secret mask.3) Another challenge I would recommend is doing the last level 'No Mercy' Loud all the way on 145+, without the bag glitch, there are no achievements for this challenge, the reward is simply knowing the fact that you have done the hardest level, on the hardest difficulty, the hardest way.The Payday Story stops abruptly and hints towards left for dead more than it does Payday 2. It honestly feels that something is missing like a payday 1.5 maybe?True there are plenty of Trolls, Hackers and Noobs in this game just like there is in Payday 2. True there are only 9 levels to grind away at while trying to reach that coveted 193 level, but it’s the level of difficulty and the constant dedication of the professional players who remain behind throwing out challenges and helping new ones that can make this game a really rewarding experience and a thumbs up.In final it is a great game to vent off some steam if you ever get a speeding fine, Thanks Overkill. Wish you were still here...

content:
8, 2013
												Note: This game been tried out and reviewed in Steam offline mode or on Consoles.Payday: The Heist is definitely one of the best downloadable titles.Payday the Heist developed by Overkill Software and released in 2011 is a coop based first person shooter falling in the same sub genre as Left For Dead. Payday essentially takes the gameplay elements from Left Four Dead and instead of a zombie setting, the game has a crime mob atmosphereThis game has been compared by the trolls as a "Left 4 Dead clone," which is horribly false. It actually does have some reliable comparisons about each games'The premise of this game is great. You get to embark on only six various heist missions and complete different tasks. You get to play with four of your Co-op friends and there is plenty of teamwork and coordination involved. However, this game is insanely unbalanced.There's almost an infinite enemy respawn, There is a ton of upgrades for instance, which comprise new guns, less recoil, better accuracy, more damage, better armor, mines, new accessories, cuffs, etcYou can also take up to three hostages (for each member of your team, unless you exchange your ammo bag for three cuffs). But you cannot even move these hostages, you basically place them on the ground, tie them up and pray that the cops won't get to them because if they do, the time for negotiation and your subsequent release from custody gets extended beyond 3 minutes. And let me tell you, once one of your team members gets caught, there is very little chance that the other 3 members will be able to hold out for the entire 3 minutes. So the whole hostage thing is moot, just ignore them, or kill them so they don't get in the wayEvery frustration that I have described so far has to do with normal difficulty. I cannot even imagine what's it like playing on Hard or OverkillI honestly have no idea what the devs were thinking about this game. Why throw that many suicidal cops and swat team members? It is so unrealistic. All they do is use smoke occasionally, send in one member with a shield or taser gun. They basically make suicidal attacks like the Japanese in WW2, so you get to mow them down and get shot at the same time. When you get shot at, your screen jerks around, your aim gets messed up and your screen gets red - the typical FPS tricksll they had to do was lessen the amount of enemies, make enemies harder to kill, make mini tasks more interesting and add a fluid cover system. However, most of the mini tasks that you need to complete do not have any meaningful cover available, so you basically run around like an idiot and try to kill as many enemies as possibleOverall: The game basically crosses the line many times over where the frustrations pile up and it's not fun anymore. The game gets repetitive and tedious pretty fast. other than that. multiplayer is fair enough but it gets boring after a while.

content:
26, 2016
												Go back to where it all began, with the 4 original heisters... Payday: The Heist. If you want a game that actually challenges you and focuses on team play, then grab this gem. With only 1 DLC ever made (excluding the in game soundtrack), this is a true video game, not a DLC fest, like Payday 2 has become.This is a straightforward team based shooter with no strings attached and has some similiar game mechanics of Left 4 Dead. It is a game where you must work hard as a team or die as a team! It is an unforgiving game and the challenges become harder as you progress, until you get to the dreaded Overkill 145+ difficulty, which is much harder than the Deathwish on Payday 2. In this game, you do not have Skills, Perk Decks, Armror or fancy weapons (RPGs) at your disposal. Because of the lack of these things, you will need to work hard and be smart with your team, to overcome the Overkill 145+ achievements.The only negative is finding a team to play with. There is only a very small amount of people who play this (probably a maximum of 300 people online at any one time). But there is plenty Payday The Heist groups and of course the forum is still reasonably active. There will always be someone out there to help you, if you don't have friends to play with.So what does this mean for you? Well, go Steal, Kill and make a Deal, in the best Payday game made.Pros:-Original concept, before it got ruined in Payday 2-Very team focused game play-Very challenging experience-No DLC every month -No micro-transactions-No cross-overs (with game or film companies)-No large downloads every month (2gigs or more, are standard updates in PD2)Cons:-Small amount of players (this can be over come by finding groups / forums to get a team)-Game can lag a lot more than Payday 2 (especially if your team is from around the world)-Some minor bugs in game, that will probably never be repairedI give this game 4 out of 5 Beers.Cheers,Frost

content:
27
 It's a mother******g BULLDOZER!! Payday: The Heist is a 2011 FPS developed by Overkill Software, and puts you in the shoes of one of four criminals who, by working together, seek to take down the next 'big score' by robbing banks, extracting prisoners, stealing diamonds and a fair amount of other stuff in between.The game plays mainly as an FPS with a couple of strategy/defense elements mixed in to the recipe: upon the start of a heist (not all, but most of them) you are given the chance to walk around the map and pick out surveillance cameras, guards, and the like, and to get into the best possible position before everything kicks off.Once the masks are on, the weapons are drawn and the yells/swear words start flying, the players are guided by their mission organiser, Bain, whom warns them of objective notifications, incoming police assaults, etc.Naturally, the cops aren't gonna shrug their shoulders and say 'eh, we'll let the interior security deal with it' are they?So they send in special units in with the waves, that are very hard for one player on their own to take out, Left 4 Dead style: The Taser can stun players, the Cloaker can incapicitate players instantly if they get within melee range, Shields carry riot shields, and (MOTHERF*****G) Bulldozers are walking tanks, deadly at short range and a pain to take down.While the game shines at its most in multiplayer, solo play is also an option, but at times the AI can be too incompetent: They always defer objectives to the player and can sometimes be a little dumb, running into firefights to try and get you back up if you go down without taking out the immediate threat first.The graphics are a little bit of a mixed bag as well. When looking around the environments, it's quite stunning, but when viewing models up close... Not so much.Despite these minor setbacks, Payday is still an awesome co-op game to play with a pal, or two, or three for an afternoon of robbery and assault. While it's sequel may have now beaten it by more than a big margin, the first game is still a great place to start, or if your rig is sadly not powerful enough.8.5/10.  A few niggling issues, but Payday: The Heist proves to be more than a solid enough entry for online co-op gameplay.

content:
ber 30, 2014
 "Damn, it feels good to be a Gangster" ‘Payday: The Heist” is a fast-paced, edgy, co-operative first-person shooter (FPS) that takes its inspiration in no small part from the fantastic Michael Mann heist flick ‘Heat’. A pulsating background score, tense entry and setup sequences, interspersed with absolute chaos once the heist is underway, make this probably one of the best Heist games ever made.Campaign | Gameplay: Released by Overkill Software / Sony Entertainment in 2011, the game consists of 7 Heists that can be played in Single-player or Co-op mode, with an additional 2 Heists available as DLC. Gamers choose to play as one of the four main protagonists – Dallas, Hoxton, Wolf or Chains – each a specialist in his own area of Heavy Weapons, Explosives, Engineering/Tech, and Sniper/Support. Each heist also consists of a series of sub-objectives – which may include locating a key target (such as a bank manager), gaining access to restricted locations, destroying surveillance footage etc. Additionally, the fact that components of these sub-objectives will randomly spawn in various locations on the map ensures that no two playthrough’s of a particular heist are exactly alike - a major bonus to the overall replayability of this title. While playable in Single-player mode (supported by 3 AI controlled bots), the game absolutely shines in Multiplayer / Co-op where each member of your 4-man crew is a different player. Obviously, the quality of your experience and ultimate success of the heist will depend on the experience of your crew – but being part of a well drilled team provides an adrenaline rush that few other games will match.Flaws: In considering its shortcomings (and there are a few) – Lack of a single player campaign, short overall length (limited to 7 Heists), average graphics, somewhat clunky K&M controls (/no controller support), text-based UI, and an overall experience targeted at a narrow cross-section of the gaming community, you might think this is a game to pass on. But,… what it does, it does brilliantly well – and the thrill of running through a heist with a top-notch crew who work together, seamlessly combine to complete objectives, cover each other’s backs and take scores is something well worth the experience. ‘Payday: The Heist’ ultimately succeeds as an homage to the great heist flicks of the past – it’s slick, fast-paced, offers a good variety of heists, and is supported by a phenomenal soundtrack. Robert de Niro (in ‘Heat’) tells it like it is: “We do what we do best – Take Scores. You do what you do best – Try to stop guys like us”. Strongly Recommended for Online Co-op / with Friends! – Rated (7.9/10) Want More Recommendations? Click the 'Follow' button on our Curator Page (Link Attached) to get the latest reviews updated directly onto your Activity Feed. Link:  'Game Syndicate - Curator Page'

 TL;DR PEOPLE THIS IS A LONG ONE, IN A NUTSHELL, 10/10 There are some people out there who don't know what this game is. Yet they know what Payday 2 is.I'm not one of those people. Payday 1, straight up and front, the father of Payday 2. Heisting, shooting, action, and some humor mixed in there. That's what Payday 1 is all about. In my personal opinion, this game is way better than Payday 2. I could go on for days, but I shortened it for you below.Pros:-Great heists. Very different from PD2. (We got Banks, Bridges, Panic Rooms, Streets, Hospitals, and even a secret vault)-Awesome and I mean AWESOME soundtrack. They set the mood for the heists.-Pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ good dialogue. ("Like a GLOVE!")-References. Most of them from heist movies, others from, well, other things. -Co-op power. Teamwork is awesome and the people on here are nice.Cons:-Premade masks. I know, I know. "But Payday 2 has customizable masks!" I DONT CAREEEEEEEE. These masks are awesome.(not that PD2's masks aren't, of course.)-Premade upgrades. Yeah, yeah, Payday 2 also has customizable upgrades. So? I got a gun, an ammo bag, cable ties and a scope. All I need.Besides that, nothing much. You probably didn't even read all the way down here. If you did, congratulations! Waste of time. Anyways, 10/10.

content:
ry 14
												Someone's gonna want to shoot me for saying this, but I don't care: I think Payday 2 is better than Payday 1.BANGWith that said, here's my comparison for the two, staying as factual as an opinion can be, so you can decide for yourself what you want.Payday 1:Pros:-Large, complex heists-RNG is much less significant, you'll never be screwed before you start.Neutral:-Very difficult. This could be a pro or con depending on your perspective, but Payday 1 will destroy you if you go in without preparing, and will probably destroy you even if you do prepare for it.Cons:-Low weapon variety-Upgrade system: The upgrades are given to you in a specific order within 1 of 4 "trees" (really, they're sticks, a straight line). This means that, even if you never use the Crosskill, you may still have to upgrade it before you can upgrade the Brenner.-Loot system- You're paid for completeing objectives, meaning that you could make potentially hundreds of thousands of dollars without ever seeing the vault (in fact, there's a farming method involving playing First World Bank on the highest difficulty, completing the first few objectives, then suiciding on the first assault wave).-Only 9 heists- it may sound like plenty, but you'll get tired of them fast as you try to max out your upgrades-Enemy AI is incompetant-Allied bots are uselessPayday 2:Pros:-Much larger variety in heists, even without DLC-More characters-Many more weapons-Upgrade system-You buy a weapon, then you modify it. No trees involved.-Stealth heists-Loot system: You're paid for securing loot. In many cases, you have to bag loot and carry it to a secure area.-Greater enemy variety-More contacts (you aren't just listening to Bain the whole time)-More variety in difficulty. Death Wish and One Down are just as hard, if not harder than, Overkill was in Payday 1, but the lower difficulties ease you into the game, allowing you to get equipment and experience to prepare you for the harder difficulties.Neutral-Enemy AI is smarter. Not by much, but it's there.-Allied bots are more useful. Again not by much (unless you want to install this: http://modworkshop.net/mydownloads.php?action=view_down&did=12736 ), but at least they can soak up tons of damage while you accomplish things.Cons:-Alot of DLC (however, sales are frequent and significant)-More simplistic heists-Weapon mods are almost entirely controlled by RNG.-RNG can screw you over easily (it's possible for a stealth run to be made near impossible by a door to the camera control room not spawning-it's not even a glitch)They're both good games, really. But if you're a newcomer, I see no point in buying Payday 1 when Payday 2 exists

content:
er 27, 2015
												PAYDAY The Heist is a 4-player co-op FPS game in which you and your friends heist your way to wealth and glory. with nine well designed heists(Two of them DLC) to keep you busy.Somehow, it manages to be better than the sequel, Payday 2, with better and more balanced weaponry, better heists, better balanced hostiles and smooth, mostly intuitive controls. That said, it is not without flaws. The stealth system is not entirely as great as in Payday 2, but that's pretty much all I can think of at the moment.The progression is decent, giving you new guns and abilities over time while giving you plenty of gametime to unlock it all. You can choose what general direction to unlock things in on leveling up, and things unlock at a steady pace that doesn't leave you grinding for levels just so you can play as you prefer. All in all, it's well made and works fine.The gameplay itself is pretty good, with cover playing an important part and no enemy feeling unfair or like an unreasonable bulletsponge. It makes sure that almost every thing you're doing is of importance, with a good pace where sometimes it is tense and other times you can take a breather. It feels like you're always doing something, whether its rejoining your group, running from cover to cover, or taking out a few special units. Somehow the drill jams less than in Payday 2 as well.Of course it's not all bad, the AI is just good enough to work, and the hordes of cops make you sometimes feel like you're playing L4D with cops instead of zombies, zombies with guns. There are surprisingly few negatives to Payday The Heist.Overall, it's a bit old, but it's still great. I'd even say better than its sequel. And with regular sales it's easy to grab some friends and go heisting. If the regular price tag is not worth it to you, a sale will probably start soon.

er 24, 2013
												This is a really entertaining and fun to play with others, kind of game.  The setting is just right, the game mechanics are there, and the music is top notch.   I remember buying it because of one thing, dynamics.   The conditions in a heist, will change.  From small things like location of items or chance of extra loot to spawn, to something larger like an entire room full of cash.   The feel of the game is there and the change in the game itself make it feel fresh, even after dozens of play troughs.   Also, there are different forms of "heists" in the game.   Most are simply "go in and grab money/items" but others are "escort person from A to B", but don't let that "A to B" analogy fool you in thinking it it easy *cough* Green Bridge *cough*.Anyway, this is just a great game to play either solo or with friends.  The only down side would be that the number of people playing it, has gone down but it is a tough yet entertaining game.  There are a few minor features here and there that are a pain, and are improved in Payday 2, but the vast majority of the game features, are all here.   Even the DLC is very well done and I HIGHLY recommend buying it as well.

content:
16, 2016
 TL:DR  Cons - The Diesel engine is old, and while it doesn't yield its ugly veil as 'well' as it does in PD2, blemishes do present themselves- No tutorial.   I always felt that a tutorial would greatly serve PD, introduce you more intimently with the enemies and Special units and their weaknesses.-Hackers.  Are everywhere.  But if you are dying to find honest heisters, check out the Payday the Heist Online sub on Reddit! Pros-THIS GAME IS HARD.    And I love it.  While I feel its a shame it doesn't have a tutorial, this game pretty drops you directly in the frey and expects you figure it out.  It makes every heist a hard earned victory, and a vigorous one at that-For whatever heisters remain, its generally a very supportive community-A DLC expansion pack that is a true bang for your buck.  Hoenstly one of the best DLC packs I've ever bought-Fantastic atmosphere!  Each of the heists stand out for a variety of reasons, and its easy to tell them aprt. Verdict It's 15 bucks.  You're not losing much, and its some of the most fun I've played online!OVERDRAWN, SOAP BOX PREACHY SEGMENT: Story Pretty much none.  Most of, if not all the missions you play in this game are extremely isolated and I like that, very much.  The base story is that you, and three of your friends are proffesional bank robbers taking on the biggest and most elaborate hits.  Ranging some simple bank heists, to raiding a panic room for cash, to even stealing blood from a patient in a hospital.  While the mission total is short, (With the games expansion pack only offering an additonal two) there can only be around 9 heists.  But the RNG makes for great staying power. Mechanics/Engine PAYDAY: The Heist is  of the two, one of the more grounded games.  It knows its engines limitations, and is sparing with the spectacles.  PAYDAY 2 on the other hand, is a much more... Outstanding game.  With PAYDAY: The Heist, you are only able to go loud for a majority of the missions, or heists.  Only one two can be stealthed, by not fully.  Working in horde based siege modes, there are four phases to a mission:Casing: You and the crew are just casing the joint.  Taking in security previsions, placements and looking for objectivesAnticipation: The heist has just gone loud.  The police have just showed up, and it's about to go down.Assault:The police will, in favor of tacticallly approching your arrest, will instead besiege the area with armed forces.  Overwhelimg your defensives, on the higher difficulty.  They have a tendancy to really throw down the gauntlet. Control: This is the phase where the police pull a tactical withdrawl.  Though only briefly.  You use this time, to med-up and restock.  In certain cases, trade allies from custody. Music This is, where the PAYDAY series has always managed to impress.  The Soundtrack, compased by Simon Viklund, then Overkill's inhouse music producer and dialogue director, impresses as always with a booming soundtrack.  While the songs can not be interchanged, like in PD2, they are much more tied into the heist you're playing.

												Aahhhh Payday: The Heist, you are like an old friend. The game is nice and simple, do this, go there, do that. It's calming. The weapons are all viable and solid, but you have limited ammo and need to preserve adding a degree of challenge. You have armor, but once that's gone you'll die fast. You feel real, like there's some high stakes involved. Then the sequel came out, bigger explosions, more weapons, mask customization, (slightly) better graphics. Sounds great right? WRONG! Everything feels extremely cluttered, you feel invincible, and there's so many things going on at once it gets really confusing. Not to mention the tenancy of new DLC every month that adds new guns, maps, and masks that are completely useless 80% of the time. Please, just buy the first. It has less maps and guns sure, but they're much more polished, smooth, and it's an immensley pleasent experience coming back to Payday after all this time.

content:
er 9, 2015
												When you first start playing, the game is hard as nails and requires strong teamwork and lots of perseverance to get through a heist on the Normal difficulty (only two heists are playable on Easy). However, once you've put in some time and level up, you become better able to survive and succeed. The game's general tempo is great, you're running around on this map constantly under pressure from the police, and periodically they'll send in tougher waves with special enemies like the "Bulldozer" (a super-armored SWAT trooper), "Shield" (a trooper with a riot shield, naturally), and "Cloaker" (a stealthy spec-ops type).There are three "classes" in the game: assault, sharpshooter, and support. While the difference between them is at first only the guns they use, as you complete missions you'll level up each class and earn more benefits. However, there's not really a system where you pick and choose your benefits: it's straight up "higher level = better", with no balances at all.One major aspect of the game's "crime" theme is the hostage concept. Civilians litter each level; shooting them causes police to act more aggressively, but they can be shouted down and zip tied to be used as hostages. If a player-character is caught by the police, they can be traded for a hostage, so in a sense hostages act as "extra lives". However, the police will also be trying to rescue the hostages, so maintaining control of them is critical.

content:
y 12, 2014
												In Payday: The Heist, players use a variety of firearms to complete objectives (usually centered around stealing a certain object, person, or a particular amount of money). The game plays from the first person perspective, but offers a few twists on the standard FPS formula. Killing civilians is punished, instead players may take a limited number as hostages. Should any player get arrested (after taking enough damage and not being 'revived' in time) during the heist, one of his teammates may release a hostage, allowing a trade to take place which allows a single player to be released. While playing the levels, players will notice a lot of variation in a single level, as there are often a large number of random events programmed in. An example of this is the location of the bank manager in First World Bank.The game focuses on four robbers (Dallas, Hoxton, Chains, and Wolf) who team up. Their first heist took place at the First World Bank, where they entered a vault by using thermite hidden on the inside of a photocopier and stole a large amount of money. A post-game message congratulates the group, telling them that they are "set for life", but recommends more heists, including robbing drug junkies in an abandoned apartment complex and ambushing a prisoner transport in heavy rain weather, simply for the enjoyment of the players.

er 17, 2014
												Ah, Payday. I got the game while it was free and I'm glad I did. A fun game where you play as one of four members of a group which robs banks and conducts other similar heists. Playing with friends is highly recommended as you will either bask in glory when you all finish that perfect bank job or yell and curse at that one guy who won't help you back up. You start off with basic weapons and skills, but these are upgraded when heists are completed, objectives are achieved, et cetera. You will find yourself constantly replaying First World Bank because it's the only one where you have a chance of finishing, but the missions are also randomised a slightly different way each time you play them.If you consider buying this game but end up going for Payday 2 instead, try and get this during a sale. The assault waves in Payday 2 are still strong, but it always seems like the cops never leave you alone in this. If you get to a stage where you find Payday 2 is too easy for you, come to this. It is still a very fun and challenging game with friends and that is what keeps me playing it.

If you watched and like movies about robbery as Point Break (1991) or Heat (1995), you will be delighted. Because each megabyte of Payday: The Heist full of references to these movies... and  to many others.Pros:+ A unique concept of cooperative game.+ Beautiful and minimalist design.+ Excellent balance.+ Hardcore.+ Additional capabilities (variability, in-game experience, challenges, customization)+ Crossover with the Left 4 Dead Universe (easter eggs, additional heist NO MERCY)+ Fair price (the game was distributed for free of charge during Crimefest)+ There is only 1 paid DLC (except OST) and no microtransactions (as in PayDay 2)Features:• Strong, but a modest content (like in Left 4 Dead)• Unideal AI (but much more smartest than in Killing Floor)• The game has no support by developers anymore (but it works perfect)• As a result - there is no anti-cheat (recommended to play with friends)Cons:- Some things should be realized much better (optimization, stealth mode, perks menu)- No support for custom modifications.8/10Outcome:ᅠPayDay: The Heist - a revolution in a particular genre of games. Cooperative robbery, wow!No more zombies, infected or mutants. Just cops and robbers. But there is a special squad, which is ready to kick your аss. And believe me, you have to make an effort that did not happen.ᅠCharacters, dialogues, sets and music - everything points to a lot of cult thrillers and action movies. This game literally consists of explicit and implicit references to ones. You will visit the deja vu on UNDERCOVER heist, in all senses.ᅠUndoubtedly, the product has some flaws. But it is necessary to take into account, that Payday: The Heist - debut(!) of Overkill Software (an independent studio at the time). It's made with lots of love, and isn't overly commercialized like PayDay 2.ᅠPayday: The Heist is able to gift you and your friends a lot of pleasant evenings and it is can be buyed during steam sale for a song. With this game you can to be in robber's shoes, not robbed. And, in case you are a big cinephile (like me), you will find yourself in paradise.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2013
												What is Payday The Heist?Well, it's a 4 player coop game. To put it short it's a wave based FPS. Mostly, players will try to hold ground and hold off the police till the objective gets done to progress further. Usually that involved drilling a vault, which takes some time. You hold out, get the loot, escape.Other than that some heist have multiple objectives to guard, thus leaving one or more behind to defend it. There are times when you need to get something fixed, so one player has to go and do that. Plus the game also has items that players can equip and share like medic bags, ammo.LevelsThe original game consists of 6 levels.Unlike Payday 2 or The Wolf's DLC, the original game's heists don't offer much variety, so you can't really go full stealth for example. One mission has stealth, but it's partial and too linear. Overkill also added an extra free mission, No Mercy, for free. Yes, it is inspired by Left 4 Dead.No Mercy & The Wolf DLC are basically the foundation of Payday 2. They are centered around dynamic events. Every time you play them, they may have items appearing at different locations, and random events happening at times.In depth look on mechanicsThe game has 3 special enemies: Bulldozer, Taser and Cloaker. It also have cops with shields and standard cops (their armor depends on the difficulty level). I think it's a very important aspect of the game. It keeps the gameplay from getting dull throughout the level.The game has armor and health: armor outlines your characters avatar in bottom right, and it can regenerate, health on the other hand can't. When you get 0 health you will be put into bleedout (last stand), after that you can either be put into custody or get saved by your teammates. Your teammates can also trade you for a hostage if you get into custody.The game also has a leveling system. 145 levels, though it's 193 if you get the DLC. You get 3 unlock trees (4 with DLC).  Each tree has 48 unlocks, and that's how you get new items, weapons and so on. It was kind of hard figuring out how to switch from one tree to another. You need to hold Tab, and either press [1], [2], [3] or [4]. By the end of the level, points are added to that tree. ConclusionThe game also has great atmosphere. Robbing banks ... well you get the idea. Just like in Left 4 Dead, you can wind up in situations where you will have to leave your friends behind. That makes for some funny moments.Friendly fire is off though (thankfully), so backstabbing isn't much of a thing.Personally i really like Payday's coop mechanics. Payday 1 is miles behind Payday 2, but the coop mechanics are pretty much the same in both games, and that what kept me playing this game for that long.DLC CompromiseThe game also has one DLC - The Wolf. It features 2 levels, but it's not necessary for you to buy the DLC to play the levels. You can join anyone who owns the DLC and play it for free. That's not a bug by the way, it's actually a really nice policy that guys at Overkill support. If you want the guns and the new upgrade tree, you will have to purchase the DLC though. It's a really fair compromise in my opinion, and most importantly, it doesn't split the community.

content:
7
												Lets get to it:Gameplay 4/5:As I'm sure you know, its a four player coop fps where you and your teammates perform different heists. Similar to the Left 4 Dead series, when you run out of health you fall down and your teammates have to come help you up before a timer runs out, but unlike L4D theres no rescue closets in this game, instead there are civilians. Players can shout at civilians to force them to the ground and then tie them up, and after a while the police will trade your teammate for a civilian, the time before the police will trade your buddy depends on how many civilians hes killed, the more killed, the longer of a wait.Assaults: Assault waves are when waves of police come and assault your team (simple enough, right?), almost every heist will begin with an assault wave. The police won't trade for civilians during an assault wavesSpecials: Just like L4D, there are four special units in the game, each one acts uniquely and is best taken care of differentlyHeists: Unfortunately there are only nine heists (six without dlc) in the game, so you can finish the game pretty quickly; fortunately each heist plays semi-uniquely. Each heist will probably take somewhere from half an hour to an hour. Theres not even a level editor.Online: Surprisingly the online community is still very active, enough so that theres still at least five people online at one amMusic 3/5:Very actiony music, suits the game wellGraphics 3/5:There graphics you would expect from a fpsOverall 3.5/5:This is one of the few games I would tell someone to purchase even while its not on sale

ry 5, 2015
												Diamond in the rough. After getting annoyed by legions of cops (every city has millions, you know?!), who are shooting you in the head from 1000m-distance, you begin to understand, that this is not your ordinary shooter (also, it's not really a heist-simulator, it's more or less a tactical PVE-shooter, in which you have to survive enemy waves, while defending one or two objectives). It's difficult, and get's even more difficult after reaching lvl 145 and unlocking the 'Overkill 145+' difficulty. But this is where the fun begins. You need to know the map, you need a plan, you need a good team with good equipment and you need balls of fire. Need a challenge? Go for Green Bridge or Heat Street on max. difficulty settings. BTW, Payday has some great and diversified missions, some even provide a stealth-approach for the team (which is not used much in the first PAYDAY game, like i said, don't expect a real heist-game) and there are some random events and variations for each and every mission. You can also level up and unlock some new weapons, perks and equipment but it's not as grindy (really not) as PAYDAY 2!PRO PVE CO-OP! fun and diversified missions challenging really good gameplayCONTRA may need some time getting into heist-theme under-utilized too much cheating going on (WTF!)This game really needed more heists, otherwise perfect experience for me...

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
20
 PAYDAY: The Heist   is the 4 player co-op FPS(first-person shooter) video game developed by  Overkill Software . This game is all about robberies and heists, given by the mysterious individual Bain, handler of the PAYDAY Crew. And obviously, you're playing as the 4 robbers, calling themselves the PAYDAY Crew: Dallas  - Mastermind of the crew, leader, wears a smiling clown mask with the American pattern.He is also depicted as the "Assault" class in the game. Hoxton  - An englishman and the "Sharpshooter" of the crew.He wears a pink and white clown mask. Chains  - An afro-american ex-marine, wears a white, blue, and pink mask. He is depicted as the "Support" class in the game. Wolf  - A swedish "Technician", demolition man, and a psychopath of the crew.Wears the white and red demon mask.Each character has its own background, morals and a sense of humor.They're bad guys, but they're badass.So, there are two mods for this game, singleplayer(just you and 3 bots, useful if you want to learn maps) and multiplayer(with randoms or friends).Before the each heist, you and your teammates must "pre-plan" it(gear up your weapons, select upgrades and crew bonuses and etc.).If you've ever played Left 4 Dead before, you'll catch on quickly, if not, don't be shy, ask your teammates about something you don't know. And i should add, this game is very  hardcore on high diffuculities, so "hold on to your butt"!And soundtrack is awesome!!!!!!Overall, if you and your friends want to have some fun, this game is definetly for you.I'm already tired to speak about it - heists, charachters, soundtrack, weapons , gagdets...bla...bla..bla ------>  9/10P.S. Buy this game and its DLC on sale, it is a little bit overpriced, but i can assure you, its definetly worth your time and money!

er 30, 2011
												PAYDAY: The Heist is a 4 player cooperative game which involves a crew of professional criminals attempting to score big by stealing various targeted items of high value. From cliche bank vaults to money printing plates, you can be sure that the local law enforcement won't make it easy for you and your crew getting out with the loot. Literally dozens of law enforcers will be dispatched to bring justice to stop your little crew from leaving the scene handcuff-free or alive.Everyone should jump at the chance to get this underrated title. Helluva rewarding game with intense gameplay with heavy cooperative elements aswell. Extra content for this game is already in the works to keep it alive. If you need a great 4 player co-op game for you and your mates to enjoy, look no further. Especially with it's cheap $20 price tag and more discounts to come, it's a steal!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2013
												Payday is an amazingly fun game. I like how simple, independent games like these always manage to get me to sink many more hours into it than any of the higher budget titles that are out. Unlike most shooters out, Payday forces you to play realistically. Your goal is not to rack up a body count, but to perform a heist. Rough around the edges, short in length, and aiming takes some time to get use to. However, in it's own way, it is very innovative. Each stage (lasting roughly 25-35 minutes) boasts with new surprises and situations depending on how you play and who you play with. No run through of any stage is ever the same. The stylish gameplay, cool concepts, and massive amounts of variety within it's few stages will keep players coming back for a very long time.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Decided to come back to this from Payday 2, and this game does not ♥♥♥♥ing dissapoint.  Whereas Payday 2 has more options and an RPG style progression, Payday: The Heist is much more linear in how the game unfolds.  You can unlock all of the skills in the game, there are a small selection of weapons, and at most the "skills" are designed to work around a party of 4.What this game lacks in choice, it makes up for one of the best heist/action movie simulators you're going to play in a long damn time.  Straight up recreations of scenes from movies, or entire movies themselves.  Rather than throw 20+ different options to complete at a heist at you, you often have one objective to complete at a time, often with dozens of cops throwing themselves at you.Holed up on a rooftop with SWAT climbing up the sides and jumping from adjacent buildings at you? Check.  Fighting your way down a crowd downtown street, chasing a traitor who stole your cash ala HEAT? Check.  Sneaking into a highrise building to steal a buttload of diamonds while holding various corporate members hostage for negotiation?  Check and check.The graphics have aged a bit, being a 5 year old game, but they get the job done and it's well optimized.  The music is absolutely amazing, and in many aspects I would count it as better than Payday 2's soundtrack.  Rather than dubstep/DnB tracks, P:TH opts for breakbeat loops with emphasis on bass, giving it a lower key but higher overall intensity feeling to the shootouts.  Rather than spending the entire match in a constant shootout with cops regardless if there's an assault in progress or not, the game gives you downtime inbetween assaults, letting the tension build before dropping you into a balls out assault wave from every direction.  It gets you in the mood and honestly keeps me coming back to the game again and again.  I particularly enjoy the Panic Room Theme, which slowly builds up as you fight your way up the derelict apartment building to the saferoom filled with cash.At $15 this game is a steal, the WolfPack DLC is unnecessary but does come with some nice skills and weapons, it's your call though since it's 66% the price of the actual vanilla game.
